verses.text: If any of you has a dispute with another, does he dare to take it before the unrighteous instead of the saints?
verses.comment: Paul challenges believers to address disputes within the community of the faithful, emphasizing the spiritual authority endowed to the saints. This mirrors Jesus' instructions on handling conflict within the church (Matt. 18).

verses.text: Do you not know that the saints will judge the world? And if the world is judged by you, are you unworthy to judge trivial cases?
verses.comment: Paul refers to the eschatological role of faithful believers sharing in Christ's authority to judge, a theme developed in Revelation and by Jesus in Matthew, highlighting a high calling for the church leaders.

verses.text: Do you not know that we will judge angels? How much more, then, matters of this life!
verses.comment: Believers are reminded of their participation in God’s greater plan, even judging angels. This calls attention to the deep spiritual authority and responsibility Christ bestows on His chosen ones.

verses.text: If you have ordinary cases, do you appoint as judges those who mean nothing in the church?
verses.comment: Paul urges the community to recognize and utilize spiritually mature members for discernment, underscoring the need for an ordered structure within the body of believers.

verses.text: I say this to shame you. Is it really so that there is no one wise among you who is able to judge between his brothers?
verses.comment: Paul’s tone is corrective, underscoring the necessity of wisdom and spiritual discernment—traits fostered by the continuous imparting of grace through the local church.

verses.text: But brother goes to law against brother, and that before unbelievers.
verses.comment: Taking disputes outside the community signifies a lack of forgiveness and humility. Jesus emphasizes reconciliation as a priority among believers, something to be achieved within the body of Christ.

verses.text: To have lawsuits at all among you is already a defeat for you. Why not rather suffer wrong? Why not rather be defrauded?
verses.comment: Paul echoes Christ's teaching about turning the other cheek, promoting self-sacrifice and love above worldly justice, reflecting a higher spiritual ethic for the church.

verses.text: Instead, you yourselves do wrong and defraud—even your own brothers.
verses.comment: The community is called to live by the golden rule and righteousness, not only avoiding injustice but treating others as true family in Christ.

verses.text: Do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived: neither the sexually immoral, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor men who practice sexual immorality with others,
verses.comment: Paul lists specific sins that separate individuals from the kingdom, emphasizing moral transformation as essential to inheriting eternal life through Christ.

verses.text: Nor thieves, nor the greedy, nor drunkards, nor slanderers, nor swindlers will inherit the kingdom of God.
verses.comment: Paul continues the catalogue of vices, urging an authentic conversion of heart through ongoing repentance and grace, drawing attention to the reality of final judgment.

verses.text: And such were some of you. But you were washed, you were sanctified, you were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and by the Spirit of our God.
verses.comment: Salvation involves being washed—pointing toward the sacramental life in Christ, and sanctification by the Spirit, showing both the objective and subjective aspects of transformation in the church.

verses.text: All things are lawful for me, but not all things are beneficial. All things are lawful for me, but I will not be mastered by anything.
verses.comment: Freedom in Christ does not mean license; true spiritual maturity is shown by choosing what leads to holiness and self-control, an emphasis on growth in virtue within the fellowship.

verses.text: Food is for the stomach and the stomach for food, but God will destroy both one and the other. The body is not for sexual immorality but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes between temporal needs and eternal purpose. The body’s real purpose is to honor and commune with the Lord, pointing subtly to the dignity of the body within the sacramental life.

verses.text: And God raised the Lord and will also raise us up through his power.
verses.comment: The resurrection of Christ is the basis and promise for believers’ resurrection, underscoring the physical and spiritual unity Christians have with Christ.

verses.text: Do you not know that your bodies are members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ and make them members of a prostitute? Never!
verses.comment: Our bodies are incorporated in Christ—a literal and mystical communion—thus, violations of chastity are not merely personal sins but wounds against Christ’s own mystical body.

verses.text: Do you not know that he who is joined to a prostitute becomes one body with her? For as it is written, 'The two will become one flesh.'
verses.comment: Paul applies Genesis to sexual union, affirming the profound spiritual reality and permanence in the union, a theme also foundational to marriage as a sacrament.

verses.text: But he who is joined to the Lord becomes one spirit with him.
verses.comment: Believers’ spiritual union with Christ mirrors marital imagery, foreshadowing the eschatological union of Christ and His Church through grace and sacramental life.

verses.text: Flee from sexual immorality. Every other sin a person commits is outside the body, but the sexually immoral person sins against his own body.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes personal holiness and the special dignity of the body, reinforcing the need for purity, and hints at the deeper consequences of sexual sin on both personal and communal aspects.

verses.text: Or do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit who is in you, whom you have from God? You are not your own,
verses.comment: Paul teaches the indwelling of the Holy Spirit, a profound reality rooted in initiation and sanctification through the church, establishing the believer’s identity and mission in Christ.

verses.text: For you were bought with a price. Therefore glorify God in your body.
verses.comment: Salvation is costly, accomplished by Christ’s sacrifice. Therefore, living out one’s faith bodily is a spiritual act of worship, pointing to the continuing call to holiness rooted in the redemption brought by Christ.
